title: As, Since, Because, Owing To, Due To, So

questions.question: We stayed inside ……………. it was raining.
questions.description: Because of and owing to are prepositions. They are followed by nouns. Because is a conjunction. It is followed by a clause.

questions.question: I wanted to leave early ……………. I was not enjoying the party.
questions.description: The conjunctions as, since and because can all be used to refer to the reason for something.

questions.question: The girl stayed at home ……………… her illness.
questions.description: Due to and owing to are interchangeable. Both of them are prepositions and are followed by nouns.

questions.question: We were late ……………. the traffic jam.
questions.description: As, since and because are conjunctions. They are followed by clauses. Because of is a preposition. It is followed by a noun.

questions.question: She didn’t love cats ………………. she wasn’t happy when her husband bought two kittens home.
questions.description: The conjunctions as, since and because introduce the reason so introduces the result.

questions.question: Ravi didn’t play …………….. his illness.
questions.description: Due to and owing to both mean because of.

questions.question: ……………. I was tired, I went to bed early.
questions.description: The conjunction as introduces the reason.

questions.question: She was very unhappy ……………. she missed her children.
questions.description: The conjunctions for and because have very similar meanings. For is common in a formal written style.

questions.question: ………………. bad weather, we cancelled the trip.
questions.description: All of the given options are possible here.

questions.question: …………… I was having a nice time, I decided to stay longer.
questions.description: We use the conjunction 'as' to show the reason.

questions.question: ……………. it was very cold, he put on his coat.
She couldn’t walk ……………. she had broken her leg.
questions.description: Because of, due to and owing to are prepositions. They cannot be followed by a clause.
